articles.headline: Extracting a Toll From a Patent ‘Troll’
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will decide whether to make it much easier for winners in patent suits to force their opponents to pay their legal fees.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will decide whether to make it much easier for winners in patent suits to force their opponents to pay their legal fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: It looks as if “patent trolls” are going to lose a big one.

articles.headline: Plea Agreement Could End SAC’s Advisory Business
articles.snippet: Winding down its business of managing money for outside investors is said to be part of a plea agreement being negotiated with prosecutors.
articles.abstract: Winding down its business of managing money for outside investors is said to be part of a plea agreement being negotiated with prosecutors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is moving closer to a plea deal with prosecutors that would force it to wind down its business of managing money for outside investors, punctuating its decline from the envy of Wall Street to a firm caught in the government’s cross hairs.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Belgian Brewery Buys U.S. Maker of Craft Beers
articles.snippet: As global brewers take interest in American craft beers, Duvel Moortgat of Belgium has acquired the Boulevard Brewing Company, the United States’ 12th-largest craft brewer.
articles.abstract: As global brewers take interest in American craft beers, Duvel Moortgat of Belgium has acquired the Boulevard Brewing Company, the United States’ 12th-largest craft brewer.
articles.lead_paragraph: As European interest in American craft beers begins to mirror the mania for them stateside, the Duvel Moortgat Brewery of Belgium on Thursday announced a deal to buy the Boulevard Brewing Company, a craft brewery in Kansas City, Mo.

articles.headline: Google Tops Estimates, but Prices of Ads Slide
articles.snippet: Google impressed investors, but people’s changing behavior on mobile phones and even on desktops threatens the company’s main business.
articles.abstract: Google impressed investors, but people’s changing behavior on mobile phones and even on desktops threatens the company’s main business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For more than a decade, Google’s search advertising business has seemed almost magical in its ability to mint money. But the magic is beginning to wear off as people spend more time on mobile devices, where the company makes less money on ads.

articles.headline: Snowden Says He Took No Secret Files to Russia
articles.snippet: In an interview, Edward J. Snowden responded to accusations by critics, provided insights into why he disclosed secret documents and talked about the debate over surveillance.
articles.abstract: In an interview, Edward J. Snowden responded to accusations by critics, provided insights into why he disclosed secret documents and talked about the debate over surveillance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, said in an extensive interview this month that he did not take any secret N.S.A. documents with him to Russia when he fled there in June, assuring that Russian intelligence officials could not get access to them.

articles.headline: From the Right, Despair, Anger and Disillusion
articles.snippet: For frustrated conservative voters, the end of the government shutdown was as much a surrender to reality as to Democratic demands.
articles.abstract: For frustrated conservative voters, the end of the government shutdown was as much a surrender to reality as to Democratic demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Tenn. — “The premise was good,” said Bob McIntire, 53, an insurance executive here in deep red Bradley County, where the local Democrats would have trouble filling up a phone booth.

articles.headline: Arizona Utility Tries Storing Solar Energy for Use in the Dark
articles.snippet: Utilities are experimenting with ways to store the sun’s energy as heat, converting it into electricity before dawn and after dusk.
articles.abstract: Utilities are experimenting with ways to store the sun’s energy as heat, converting it into electricity before dawn and after dusk.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it snowed in Flagstaff, Ariz., recently, thousands of people woke up and turned up their electric heating, and Arizona Public Service saw electricity demand reach a morning peak. To meet the demand, the company used the previous afternoon’s sunshine.

articles.headline: Two Parties Start Work to Avoid Repeat Crisis
articles.snippet: The need for a bipartisan breakthrough, even a modest one, was amplified by the economic costs wrought by the 16-day shutdown and near-default on government obligations.
articles.abstract: The need for a bipartisan breakthrough, even a modest one, was amplified by the economic costs wrought by the 16-day shutdown and near-default on government obligations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the government reopened and a debt default averted for now, Congressional negotiators on Thursday plunged into difficult budget talks to avoid a repeat crisis within months, and quickly agreed to lower their sights from the sort of grand bargain that has eluded the two parties for three years.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jackie Calmes
